Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story:
This morning, I woke up to the sound of my husband bustling around the kitchen, reminding me that his parents and siblings would be arriving in just a few hours. The house was a mess—dishes piled up, laundry still in baskets, and the guest room needed fresh sheets. He looked at me expectantly, hoping I’d help him get everything ready. I knew he counted on me to share the load, especially when it came to making a good impression on his family.

But as I glanced at the clock, my heart sank. My volunteer shift started in less than an hour, and today, I was the only one scheduled to open the community center. People would already be waiting outside, some of them relying on our services for their morning meal. If I didn’t show up on time, the doors would stay locked, and those people would be left standing in the cold.

I could feel the pressure mounting from both sides—my husband’s anxious glances, the mental image of the waiting crowd. I stood in the hallway, keys in one hand, cleaning spray in the other, torn between the home that needed me and the community that depended on me.
